item.title: Recovering data in Linux ext4
item.description: Introduction Have you ever removed a file with rm [FILENAME] or even worse rm -rf [DIR] only to find out that that you didn’t have a backup?. Well this happend to me with a project I hadn’t pushed to Github, and could not recover despite my best efforts, coloquially I know that the file wasn’t really deleted, it was just stored in unallocated spaces and the pointers from the filesystem datastructures where no longer pointing to it, so the file was recoverable but I didn’t know how to get it back.

item.title: Helm3-secrets on KMS
item.description: Setup / Prerequisites A working Kubenetes (GKE) Helm3 KMS Permissions Sops (https://github.com/mozilla/sops/) Let’s Do it! Key Generation First off you need to create a user in IAM with permissions (KMS Admin), and setup gcloud with this user After this, create a key ring and keys with the following comands: gcloud kms keyrings create helm \ --location us-west1 gcloud kms keys create helm-secrets \ --location us-west1 \ --keyring helm \ --purpose "encryption" --rotation-period "90d" \ --next-rotation-time "2020-05-30T01:00:00" This will create a key ring named helm with a key called helm-secrets in us-west1 with a 90 day rotation period starting on May 30th 2020.

item.title: Who am I?
item.description: #Who Am I? I am a Chilean Software Engineer turned Devops Engineer, although I code by day I attempt to do security research by night in whatever peaks my interest, usually these days its forensics and android, but I am hoping to shift gears to Kubernetes Security sometime in the future. This blog serves as my attempt to document whatever the hell I’m up to. I wrote my thesis on android reverse engineering when graduating from UTFSM in Chile, it was a fun experience that brought me closer to the security world, today I’m working as a Kubernetes Engieer and trying to absorb the knoweledge from that world and figure out some way to apply it to security.

item.title: Reverse Engineering Android Applications and Threat Intelligence
item.description: Introduction This was my graduate thesis, in which I reversed engineered and android APK application, to then use a metasploit payload to launch malware from the infected app and then proceeded to attempt anti virus evasion. I go through the android permission model, applicaiton settings and how app signing works. An overview of ARM architecture, to move on to a list of tools I used to reverse engineer, including Metasploit and APKTool.
